skill.name: global-conventions
skill.description: Follow project-wide development conventions including project structure, version control practices, environment configuration, documentation, dependency management, and code review processes. Use this skill when organizing files/directories, writing commit messages, managing branches, configuring environments, handling secrets, maintaining documentation, or establishing team workflows. Apply when working with project structure, README files, .gitignore, environment variables, dependency files (package.json, requirements.txt), feature flags, changelogs, or any aspect of project organization and team collaboration that requires consistency across the development lifecycle.
skill.summary: Enforce consistent development practices across project structure, version control, and documentation
skill.author: EIS-ITS

security_audit.summary: This skill is safe for publication. Static analysis detected 22 potential patterns but all were false positives. The skill contains only documentation and guidance references with no executable code. All network and filesystem detections were triggered by metadata fields and documentation text, not actual security risks.

content.value_statement: Managing development conventions across teams is challenging and leads to inconsistent code quality. This skill guides Claude Code to follow your project-wide standards for structure, version control, documentation, and workflows.
actual_capabilities: Guide file and directory organization according to project standards
Format commit messages and pull requests following team conventions
Manage environment configuration files and secrets appropriately
Maintain consistent documentation across README files and changelogs
Apply dependency management practices for package files
Follow code review processes and testing requirements
limitations: Requires external convention documentation file to reference
Does not automatically enforce conventions without user guidance
Cannot modify existing project files without user permission
Effectiveness depends on quality of referenced convention documentation

use_cases.title: Standardize Project Structure
use_cases.description: Software engineers can ensure new features follow established directory layouts and file naming patterns

use_cases.title: Enforce Git Workflow Compliance
use_cases.description: DevOps teams can maintain consistent branch naming, commit message formats, and merge request standards

use_cases.title: Maintain Documentation Quality
use_cases.description: Technical writers can ensure README files, changelogs, and API docs follow organizational templates

prompt_templates.title: Basic Convention Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my project structure and suggest improvements based on global conventions
prompt_templates.scenario: Quick validation of current project organization

prompt_templates.title: Format Commit Message
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write a commit message for these changes following our team conventions

prompt_templates.title: Configure Environment Files
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up environment configuration files following security and documentation best practices

prompt_templates.title: Establish New Project Standards
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a complete project structure with README, gitignore, and dependency files following our conventions for a new microservice
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting new projects with consistent foundation

output_examples.input: Review my commit message: fixed bug
output_examples.output: Your commit message should follow the conventional format: type(scope): description. Consider: fix(auth): resolve token expiration issue in login flow

output_examples.input: Where should I put my configuration files?
output_examples.output: Based on global conventions, configuration files should be organized as follows: environment-specific configs in /config directory, secrets in .env files (excluded from version control), and documentation in /docs. Always reference environment variables rather than hardcoding values.

best_practices: Reference the skill when starting new features to ensure proper project organization from the beginning
Use the skill to review existing code before pull requests to catch convention violations early
Combine with code review workflows to maintain consistent standards across the team
anti_patterns: Do not use this skill to override security requirements or bypass necessary approval processes
Avoid applying conventions blindly without understanding project-specific context and requirements
Do not use outdated convention references without verifying they match current team standards

faq.question: Does this skill automatically fix convention violations?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance to Claude Code. It will suggest changes and help implement them, but requires user approval before modifying files.

faq.question: Can I customize the conventions for my team?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill references an external conventions file. You can modify that documentation to reflect your team specific standards.

faq.question: Will this skill work without the referenced convention file?
faq.answer: The skill requires access to the convention documentation file. Without it, Claude Code will use general best practices but cannot enforce project specific standards.

faq.question: How does this skill handle conflicts between conventions?
faq.answer: The skill prioritizes project specific conventions from the referenced documentation. When conflicts arise, it will ask for clarification on which standard to follow.

faq.question: Can this skill help with existing legacy projects?
faq.answer: Yes, you can use this skill to gradually refactor legacy code toward modern conventions. It can identify inconsistencies and suggest incremental improvements.

faq.question: Does this skill support multiple programming languages?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill focuses on language agnostic conventions like project structure, version control, and documentation. Language specific standards should be defined in the referenced convention file.
